items.title: Trump revokes US scientific finding behind climate change regulations

items.content: Trump administration rescinds 'endangerment finding' that serves as the legal bases to curb greenhouse gas emissions.

items.title: Trump scraps legal basis for climate rules
items.standfirst: It's been billed by the White House as the 'largest deregulatory action in US history' - Donald Trump has formally revoked a landmark scientific finding that greenhouse gases endanger public health by driving climate change - a determination that underpins regulations aimed at curbing planet-warming pollution. The repeal is expected to be swiftly challenged in the courts. France 24's Sharon Gaffney speaks with Meredith Hankins, federal climate legal director at the US-based NGO, National Resources Defence Council.
items.content: It's been billed by the White House as the 'largest deregulatory action in US history' - Donald Trump has formally revoked a landmark scientific finding that greenhouse gases endanger public health by driving climate change - a determination that underpins regulations aimed at curbing planet-warming pollution. The repeal is expected to be swiftly challenged in the courts. France 24's Sharon Gaffney speaks with Meredith Hankins, federal climate legal director at the US-based NGO, National Resources Defence Council.

items.title: EPA chief Lee Zeldin asked if "endangerment finding" repeal will harm public health, environment
items.standfirst: President Trump has overturned the 2009 "endangerment finding" that greenhouse gas emissions pose a danger to human health. It provided the Environmental Protection Agency with the authority to regulate carbon emissions. In an exclusive interview, EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin defended the move to CBS News senior White House correspondent Weijia Jiang.
items.content: President Trump has overturned the 2009 "endangerment finding" that greenhouse gas emissions pose a danger to human health. It provided the Environmental Protection Agency with the authority to regulate carbon emissions. In an exclusive interview, EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin defended the move to CBS News senior White House correspondent Weijia Jiang.

items.title: Trump revokes Obama-era climate finding on greenhouse gas risks
items.standfirst: The Trump administration on Thursday revoked a long-standing scientific finding underpinning US efforts to regulate greenhouse gas emissions, marking its most sweeping rollback of climate policy. The Environmental Protection Agency rescinded the 2009 “endangerment finding,” which determined carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases threaten public health and welfare.
items.content: The Trump administration on Thursday revoked a long-standing scientific finding underpinning US efforts to regulate greenhouse gas emissions, marking its most sweeping rollback of climate policy. The Environmental Protection Agency rescinded the 2009 “endangerment finding,” which determined carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases threaten public health and welfare.

clusters.title: Bangladesh election: BNP claims win in historic first election since overthrow of Hasina

items.title: Bangladesh election: BNP claims win in historic first election since overthrow of Hasina
items.standfirst: Voting was largely peaceful in an election seen as a test of Bangladesh’s democracy after years of political turmoil under autocratic rulerThe Bangladesh Nationalist party (BNP) led by Tarique Rahman has claimed a sweeping victory in the country’s first election since a gen-Z uprising toppled the autocratic regime of Sheikh Hasina.By Friday morning, results had shown a clear win for the party, returning them to power after 20 years. It had been seen as the first free and fair election held in Bangladesh for almost two decades and came after a period of significant political upheaval in the country. Continue reading...

It had been seen as the first free and fair election held in Bangladesh for almost two decades and came after a period of significant political upheaval in the country. Continue reading...

items.standfirst: Jailed then exiled in London, Rahman returns home as the main contender to be next prime minister of BangladeshTarique Rahman, who after 17 years in exile is the main contender to be the next prime minister of Bangladesh, has pledged to end entrenched corruption and put the country on a “new path” as voting began in the first free and fair elections in almost two decades.Speaking to the Guardian before polls opened on Thursday morning, Rahman promised a new era of clean politics, including a “top down, no tolerance” approach to graft, if his Bangladesh Nationalist party (BNP) was brought to power. Continue reading...

clusters.title: AI safety leader says 'world is in peril' and quits to study poetry
clusters.neutral_headline: AI Safety Leader Quits Over ChatGPT Ads

items.title: AI safety leader says 'world is in peril' and quits to study poetry
items.standfirst: It comes in the same week an OpenAI researcher resigned amid concerns about its decision to start testing ChatGPT ads.
items.content: It comes in the same week an OpenAI researcher resigned amid concerns about its decision to start testing ChatGPT ads.

items.title: OpenAI researcher quits over ChatGPT ads, warns of "Facebook" path
items.standfirst: Zoë Hitzig resigned on the same day OpenAI began testing ads in its chatbot.
items.content: On Wednesday, former OpenAI researcher Zoë Hitzig published a guest essay in The New York Times announcing that she resigned from the company on Monday, the same day OpenAI began testing advertisements inside ChatGPT. Hitzig, an economist and published poet who holds a junior fellowship at the Harvard Society of Fellows, spent two years at OpenAI helping shape how its AI models were built and priced. She wrote that OpenAI's advertising strategy risks repeating the same mistakes that Facebook made a decade ago. "I once believed I could help the people building A.I. get ahead of the problems it would create," Hitzig wrote. "This week confirmed my slow realization that OpenAI seems to have stopped asking the questions I'd joined to help answer." Hitzig did not call advertising itself immoral. Instead, she argued that the nature of the data at stake makes ChatGPT ads especially risky. Users have shared medical fears, relationship problems, and religious beliefs with the chatbot, she wrote, often "because people believed they were talking to something that had no ulterior agenda." She called this accumulated record of personal disclosures "an archive of human candor that has no precedent."Read full article Comments

ai_summary: OpenAI researcher resigns amid concerns
Zoë Hitzig warns of Facebook path for ChatGPT
Resignation comes as OpenAI tests ads
Move sparks debate on AI safety and ethics
Hitzig to study poetry after leaving OpenAI

clusters.title: Venezuela postpones vote on amnesty bill to protect political dissidents

items.title: Venezuela postpones vote on amnesty bill to protect political dissidents
items.standfirst: Venezuelan lawmakers on Thursday postponed a landmark amnesty bill meant to halt the use of courts against dissenters after failing to agree on its implementation. Thousands rallied in Caracas demanding the release of political prisoners. The bill would clear charges against opponents of former leaders Nicolas Maduro and Hugo Chavez.
items.content: Venezuelan lawmakers on Thursday postponed a landmark amnesty bill meant to halt the use of courts against dissenters after failing to agree on its implementation. Thousands rallied in Caracas demanding the release of political prisoners. The bill would clear charges against opponents of former leaders Nicolas Maduro and Hugo Chavez.

items.title: Venezuela opposition rally calls on post-Maduro govt to grant full freedoms
items.standfirst: Thousands of people on Thursday joined a Caracas opposition rally calling on the country’s interim government to release all political prisoners and grant Venezuelans full freedoms. The demonstration came as lawmakers were set to debate a landmark amnesty bill granting clemency to people jailed for participating in political protests, but they ultimately voted to postpone its adoption.
items.content: Thousands of people on Thursday joined a Caracas opposition rally calling on the country’s interim government to release all political prisoners and grant Venezuelans full freedoms. The demonstration came as lawmakers were set to debate a landmark amnesty bill granting clemency to people jailed for participating in political protests, but they ultimately voted to postpone its adoption.

items.title: Venezuelans rally more openly as they navigate changing political landscape
items.standfirst: As people participate in more protests, they’re demanding the government release political prisoners as it has pledged to do.

items.standfirst: European Union leaders on Thursday agreed on an action plan to overhaul the bloc’s economy and boost competitiveness amid pressure from US President Donald Trump, China and Russia. European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen said the March plan would upgrade energy grids, deepen financial integration and ease merger rules.

clusters.neutral_headline: Boy Swims For Hours To Save Family

items.title: Police release call from boy, 13, who swam for hours to save his family stranded at sea
items.standfirst: Authorities have released the audio of an emergency call made by a 13-year-old boy who swam for hours to save his family after they were swept out to sea.
items.content: Authorities have released the audio of an emergency call made by a 13-year-old boy who swam for hours to save his family after they were swept out to sea.

items.title: Emergency call released of boy who swam for hours to save family
items.standfirst: Austin Appelbee, 13, swam to get help for his mother and siblings after they were swept out to sea.
items.content: Austin Appelbee, 13, swam to get help for his mother and siblings after they were swept out to sea.

ai_summary: A 13-year-old boy swam for hours to save family
The family was swept out to sea
The boy made an emergency call for help
Authorities released the audio of the call
The boy's name is Austin Appelbee
